anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ray, J. This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment dated 28 March, 1968 of the High Court at Calcutta quashing the processes issued against the three

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment dated 28 March 1968 of Calcutta High Court quashing processes against three accused.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment dated 28 March, 1968 of the High Court at Calcutta quashing the processes issued against the three accused persons. The appellant on 8 March, 1966 filed a

facts.text: Appellant filed complaint on 8 March 1966 against Block Development Officer Purulia, Officer-in-Charge local Police Station, and T. Ganguly DSP Purulia under section 395 IPC alleging dacoity during search of appellant's house.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant on 8 March, 1966 filed a petition of companyplaint against the Block Development Officer Purulia, the Officer- in Charge of the local Police Station and T. Ganguly, the Deputy Superintendent of Police, Purulia under section 395 of the Indian Penal Code on the allegation that during search of the appellants house they companymitted dacoity in the house. The Magistrate dismissed the companyplaint under section 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure on the ground that the companyplaint was incompetent without sanction as the accused were Government servants.

facts.text: Magistrate dismissed the complaint under section 203 CrPC on ground that complaint was incompetent without sanction as accused were Government servants.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate dismissed the companyplaint under section 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure on the ground that the companyplaint was incompetent without sanction as the accused were Government servants. The companyplainant thereafter moved the Sessions Judge, Purulia against the order of dismissal. A reference was made to the Calcutta High Court.

facts.text: Complainant moved Sessions Judge Purulia against the order of dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant thereafter moved the Sessions Judge, Purulia against the order of dismissal. A reference was made to the Calcutta High Court. The learned Single Judge of the Calcutta High Court accepted the reference, set aside the order of the Magistrate and sent the case back for proceeding in accordance with law.

facts.text: Reference made to Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: A reference was made to the Calcutta High Court. The learned Single Judge of the Calcutta High Court accepted the reference, set aside the order of the Magistrate and sent the case back for proceeding in accordance with law. On 27 March, 1967 the Magistrate Shri S. K. Ganguly took companynizance of the case and fixed a date for holding judicial enquiry.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court Single Judge accepted reference, set aside Magistrate's order, sent case back for proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge of the Calcutta High Court accepted the reference, set aside the order of the Magistrate and sent the case back for proceeding in accordance with law. On 27 March, 1967 the Magistrate Shri S. K. Ganguly took companynizance of the case and fixed a date for holding judicial enquiry. The Magistrate on 22 November, 1967 came to the companyclusion that a prima facie case under section 395 of the Indian Penal Code had been made out against the three accused and submitted a report to the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Purulia.

facts.text: On 27 March 1967, Magistrate Shri S. K. Ganguly took cognizance and fixed date for judicial enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: On 27 March, 1967 the Magistrate Shri S. K. Ganguly took companynizance of the case and fixed a date for holding judicial enquiry. The Magistrate on 22 November, 1967 came to the companyclusion that a prima facie case under section 395 of the Indian Penal Code had been made out against the three accused and submitted a report to the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Purulia. The Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Purulia on receipt of the report of the judicial enquiry passed an order on 6 December, 1.967 directing the issue of process against all the three accused.

facts.text: On 22 November 1967, Magistrate concluded prima facie case under section 395 IPC against three accused and submitted report to SDM Purulia.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate on 22 November, 1967 came to the companyclusion that a prima facie case under section 395 of the Indian Penal Code had been made out against the three accused and submitted a report to the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Purulia. The Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Purulia on receipt of the report of the judicial enquiry passed an order on 6 December, 1.967 directing the issue of process against all the three accused. This order forms the subject matter of the appeal.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate Purulia on 6 December 1967 ordered issue of process against all three accused.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Purulia on receipt of the report of the judicial enquiry passed an order on 6 December, 1.967 directing the issue of process against all the three accused. This order forms the subject matter of the appeal. One of the accused thereafter moved the High Court at Calcutta for quashing the process.

facts.text: This order of SDM issuing process is the subject matter of the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: This order forms the subject matter of the appeal. One of the accused thereafter moved the High Court at Calcutta for quashing the process. The High Court at Calcutta said that companynizance of the offence was taken by the Magistrate Shri S. K. Ganguly but process was issued by the Magistrate Shri S. Sarkar and held that Shri Sarkar number having taken companynizance of the offence had numberright to issue process under section 204 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: One of the accused moved Calcutta High Court to quash the process.

anchor.surface_text: One of the accused thereafter moved the High Court at Calcutta for quashing the process. The High Court at Calcutta said that companynizance of the offence was taken by the Magistrate Shri S. K. Ganguly but process was issued by the Magistrate Shri S. Sarkar and held that Shri Sarkar number having taken companynizance of the offence had numberright to issue process under section 204 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The High Court, therefore, quashed the process and observed that the learned Magistrate who had taken companynizance of the offence if he was so advised would be at liberty to issue processes against the other two accused persons.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court held that cognizance taken by Shri S.K. Ganguly but process issued by Shri S. Sarkar who had no right under s.204 CrPC, quashed process.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court at Calcutta said that companynizance of the offence was taken by the Magistrate Shri S. K. Ganguly but process was issued by the Magistrate Shri S. Sarkar and held that Shri Sarkar number having taken companynizance of the offence had numberright to issue process under section 204 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The High Court, therefore, quashed the process and observed that the learned Magistrate who had taken companynizance of the offence if he was so advised would be at liberty to issue processes against the other two accused persons. The question for companysideration is whether Shri Sarkar companyld have issued process in the-present case.

facts.text: High Court observed that Magistrate who took cognizance (Ganguly) at liberty to issue processes against other two accused.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, therefore, quashed the process and observed that the learned Magistrate who had taken companynizance of the offence if he was so advised would be at liberty to issue processes against the other two accused persons. The question for companysideration is whether Shri Sarkar companyld have issued process in the-present case. Shri Ganguly was the Magistrate who took companynizance. Shri Sarkar was number the Magistrate who took companynizance.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that High Court correctly quashed the issue of process.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court therefore companyrectly quashed the issue of process. It was companytended on behalf of the appellant that the High Court should number have gone to the question as to whether a prima facie case was established or number. The High Court under section 561-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure can go into the question as to whether there is any legal evidence.

facts.text: Appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companyrectly quashed the process against T. Ganguly. The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation requires transfers to originate from cognizance-taking Magistrate on application or discretion

holdings.text: The relevant section which confers power on the Magistrate to whom the case has been transferred to issue process is section 202 of the Code of Criminal Procedure

anchor.surface_text: The relevant section which confers power on the Magistrate to whom the case has been transferred to issue process is section 202 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The language of section 202 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is that the Magistrate may, for reasons to be recorded in writing, postpone the issue of process for compelling the attendance of the person complained against. Therefore the power of the Magistrate to issue process under section 202 of the Code, of Criminal Procedure is not limited by the terms of section,204 of. the Code-of Criminal Procedure to issue process.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.202 provides distinct power for transferee Magistrates, harmonious with s.204

anchor.surface_text: Sections 191 and 192 of the Code of Criminal Procedure contemplate transfer of cases by a Magistrate, who has taken cognizance, of an offence. Section 191 of the Code of Criminal procedure contemplates transfer of a case or commitment to the Court of sessions on the application of the accused. Section 192 of the Code of Criminal Procedure speaks of transfer of a case by a Magistrate who has taken cognizance to any Magistrate subordinate to him for enquiry or trial. In these cases where either the Magistrate has taken cognizance and is in se
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding on Section 202 power for transferee addresses whether Shri Sarkar could issue process

anchor.surface_text: The relevant section which confers power on the Magistrate to whom the case has been transferred to issue process is section 202 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The language of section 202 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is that the Magistrate may, for reasons to be recorded in writing, postpone the issue of process for compelling the attendance of the person complained against. Therefore the power of the Magistrate to issue process under section 202 of the Code, of Criminal Procedure is not limited by the terms of section,204 of. the Code-of Criminal Procedure to issue process.
